trans-unit.source: Securing cloud resources with Azure Multi-Factor Authentication and AD FS
trans-unit.target: Securing cloud resources with Azure Multi-Factor Authentication and AD FS

trans-unit.source: If your organization is federated with Azure Active Directory and you have resources that are accessed by Azure AD, you can use Azure Multi-Factor Authentication or Active Directory Federation Services to secure these resources.
trans-unit.target: If your organization is federated with Azure Active Directory and you have resources that are accessed by Azure AD, you can use Azure Multi-Factor Authentication or Active Directory Federation Services to secure these resources.

trans-unit.source: Use the procedures below to secure Azure Active Directory resources with either Azure Multi-Factor Authentication or Active Directory Federation Services.
trans-unit.target: Use the procedures below to secure Azure Active Directory resources with either Azure Multi-Factor Authentication or Active Directory Federation Services.

trans-unit.source: Trusted IPs for federated users
trans-unit.target: Trusted IPs for federated users

trans-unit.source: Trusted IPs allow administrators to by-pass multi-factor authentication for specific IP address or for federated users that have requests originating from within their own intranet.
trans-unit.target: Trusted IPs allow administrators to by-pass multi-factor authentication for specific IP address or for federated users that have requests originating from within their own intranet.

trans-unit.source: The following sections will describe how to configure Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Trusted IPs with federated users and by-pass multi-factor authentication, when a request originates from within a federated users intranet.
trans-unit.target: The following sections will describe how to configure Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Trusted IPs with federated users and by-pass multi-factor authentication, when a request originates from within a federated users intranet.

trans-unit.source: This is achieved by configuring AD FS to use a pass through or filter an incoming claim template with the Inside Corporate Network claim type.
trans-unit.target: This is achieved by configuring AD FS to use a pass through or filter an incoming claim template with the Inside Corporate Network claim type.

trans-unit.source: This example uses Office 365 for our Relying Party Trusts.

trans-unit.source: Configure the AD FS claims rules
trans-unit.target: Configure the AD FS claims rules

trans-unit.source: The first thing we need to do is to configure the AD FS claims.
trans-unit.target: The first thing we need to do is to configure the AD FS claims.

trans-unit.source: We will be creating two claims rules, one for the Inside the Corporate Network claim type and an additional one for keeping our users signed in.
trans-unit.target: We will be creating two claims rules, one for the Inside the Corporate Network claim type and an additional one for keeping our users signed in.

trans-unit.source: Open AD FS Management.
trans-unit.target: Open AD FS Management.

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Relying Party Trusts.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Relying Party Trusts.

trans-unit.source: In the middle, right-click on Microsoft Office 365 Identity Platform and select **Edit Claim Rules…**
trans-unit.target: In the middle, right-click on Microsoft Office 365 Identity Platform and select **Edit Claim Rules…**

trans-unit.source: ![Cloud](./media/multi-factor-authentication-get-started-adfs-cloud/trustedip1.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Cloud](./media/multi-factor-authentication-get-started-adfs-cloud/trustedip1.png)

trans-unit.source: On Issuance Transform Rules click **Add Rule.**
trans-unit.target: On Issuance Transform Rules click **Add Rule.**

trans-unit.source: ![Cloud](./media/multi-factor-authentication-get-started-adfs-cloud/trustedip2.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Cloud](./media/multi-factor-authentication-get-started-adfs-cloud/trustedip2.png)

trans-unit.source: On the Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard, select Pass Through or Filter an Incoming Claim from the drop down and click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard, select Pass Through or Filter an Incoming Claim from the drop down and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: In the box next to Claim rule name, give your rule a name.
trans-unit.target: In the box next to Claim rule name, give your rule a name.

trans-unit.source: For example: InsideCorpNet.
trans-unit.target: For example: InsideCorpNet.

trans-unit.source: From the drop-down, next to Incoming claim type, select Inside Corporate Network.
trans-unit.target: From the drop-down, next to Incoming claim type, select Inside Corporate Network.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: On Issuance Transform Rules click **Add Rule**.
trans-unit.target: On Issuance Transform Rules click **Add Rule**.

trans-unit.source: On the Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard, select Send Claims Using a Custom Rule from the drop down and click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard, select Send Claims Using a Custom Rule from the drop down and click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the box under Claim rule name: enter Keep Users Signed In.
trans-unit.target: In the box under Claim rule name: enter Keep Users Signed In.

trans-unit.source: In the Custom rule box enter:
trans-unit.target: In the Custom rule box enter:

trans-unit.target: Click **Ok**.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Trusted IPs with Federated Users
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Trusted IPs with Federated Users

trans-unit.source: Now that the claims are in place, we cane configure trusted ips.
trans-unit.target: Now that the claims are in place, we cane configure trusted ips.

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the left, click Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Under, Directory click on the directory you wish to setup Trusted IPs on.
trans-unit.target: Under, Directory click on the directory you wish to setup Trusted IPs on.

trans-unit.source: On the Directory you have selected, click Configure.
trans-unit.target: On the Directory you have selected, click Configure.

trans-unit.source: In the multi-factor authentication section, click Manage service settings.
trans-unit.target: In the multi-factor authentication section, click Manage service settings.

trans-unit.source: On the Service Settings page, under Trusted IPs, select **For requests from federated users originating from my intranet.**
trans-unit.target: On the Service Settings page, under Trusted IPs, select **For requests from federated users originating from my intranet.**

trans-unit.source: ![Cloud](./media/multi-factor-authentication-get-started-adfs-cloud/trustedip6.png)

trans-unit.source: Click save.
trans-unit.target: Click save.

trans-unit.source: Once the updates have been applied, click close.
trans-unit.target: Once the updates have been applied, click close.

trans-unit.source: That’s it!
trans-unit.target: That’s it!

trans-unit.source: At this point, federated Office 365 users should only have to use MFA when a claim originates from outside the corporate intranet.
trans-unit.target: At this point, federated Office 365 users should only have to use MFA when a claim originates from outside the corporate intranet.
